title: 106_s2885
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission Act of 2000". The founding of Jamestown in 1607 brought together people from different backgrounds to form a multicultural society. The institutions developed during its first 9 decades continue to influence the United States in various aspects. The National Park Service, the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, and the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation collectively own and operate resources related to Jamestown's early history. In 1996, the Commonwealth of Virginia designated the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation to plan and implement the commemoration of the 400th anniversary of Jamestown's founding. Planning for the commemoration began with the creation of the Celebration 2007 Steering Committee. The Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission was established to ensure a national observance of the Jamestown 2007 anniversary, cooperate with Virginia's programs, assist in providing a great visitor experience, and recognize all people present in 17th century Jamestown. The Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission aims to support Jamestown-related programs, facilitate international involvement in the 2007 observances, assist in marketing efforts for commemorative items, and promote heritage tourism and economic benefits to the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Commemoration - 400th anniversary of Jamestown settlement.
(2) Commission - Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission.
(3) Governor - Governor of Virginia.
(4) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
(5) State - Commonwealth of Virginia, including its agencies and entities. The Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission is established with 15 members, including appointments by the Secretary based on recommendations from the Jamestown 2007 Steering Committee and the Governor, as well as employees of the National Park Service. The Jamestown 400th Commemoration Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the Secretary, including employees of the National Park Service and individuals with relevant expertise. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission members serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies are filled to complete the term. Meetings are held at least twice a year or as called by the Chairperson. Voting requires an affirmative majority. The Commission, with a majority constituting a quorum, is responsible for planning and executing programs to commemorate the 400th anniversary of Jamestown's founding. The Secretary appoints a Chairperson, who oversees Jamestown-related activities nationwide and encourages various organizations to participate in anniversary events. The Commission is responsible for planning and executing programs to commemorate the 400th anniversary of Jamestown's founding. They coordinate scholarly research, publication, and interpretation of Jamestown, ensuring a lasting legacy through appropriate programs and facilities. They prepare a strategic plan and annual performance plans in accordance with the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993. The Commission is responsible for planning and executing programs to commemorate the 400th anniversary of Jamestown's founding. They prepare a strategic plan, annual performance plans, and a final report containing activities, funds, findings, and recommendations. The Commission has the power to accept donations and disperse funds related to Jamestown's significance in U.S. history. The Commission has the authority to appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, procure supplies, use the United States mails, and make grants up to $10,000 to communities and nonprofit organizations. The Commission has the authority to appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, procure supplies, make grants up to $10,000, and provide technical assistance to further the commemoration. Members of the Commission serve without compensation, except for Federal employees who receive their regular compensation. The Commission appoints advisory committees, authorizes actions, procures supplies, makes grants up to $10,000, and provides technical assistance. Members serve without compensation, except for Federal employees who receive their regular compensation. Commission members are allowed travel expenses and the Chairperson can appoint necessary staff without following civil service laws. The Commission appoints advisory committees, authorizes actions, procures supplies, makes grants up to $10,000, and provides technical assistance. Members serve without compensation, except for Federal employees who receive their regular compensation. The Chairperson can appoint necessary staff without following civil service laws. The employment of an executive director is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and the Chairperson may fix their compensation without regard to certain pay rate regulations. The executive director's compensation shall not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agency personnel can be detailed to assist the Commission without losing civil service status. The Commission may accept personnel from States and reimburse them for services. They can also use voluntary and uncompensated services. The National Park Service will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission's authority does not supersede that of the State, National Park Service, or the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 2008. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
